message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about celestial objects and their movement in the sky. At nighttime, when it is dark, we can see the stars and other celestial objects. The Big Dipper is a well-known constellation that can be seen in the northern hemisphere and is visible throughout the night during certain times of the year. It does not "disappear over the horizon." Option (A) is incorrect because the horizon does not change significantly at nighttime. Option (B) is incorrect because the Sun is not visible at nighttime. Option (C) is incorrect because mountains do not change their position significantly at nighttime unless there are specific geological phenomena occurring.

This question requires basic knowledge about celestial objects and their visibility during nighttime. At nighttime, when the Sun has set, we cannot see changing views of the Sun (option B) because it is no longer visible. Option A, changing views of the horizon, can occur during sunrise or sunset but not specifically at nighttime. Option C, changing views of mountains, may occur due to factors like lighting or weather conditions, but it is not directly related to nighttime. Option D, the Big Dipper disappearing over the horizon, is the most likely scenario because the Big Dipper is a prominent constellation that is visible during certain seasons and may appear to move as the Earth rotates.

At nighttime, the Earth rotates on its axis, causing the stars and constellations to appear to move across the sky. The Big Dipper is a well-known constellation that is visible in the Northern Hemisphere. Throughout the night, as the Earth continues to rotate, the Big Dipper will appear to move across the sky and eventually disappear over the horizon. Option (A) is incorrect because the horizon remains relatively fixed throughout the night. Option (B) is incorrect because the Sun is not visible at nighttime. Option (C) is also incorrect because mountains do not have the same movement as celestial objects in the sky.
